docs.title: Peregrine L1
docs.text:
Tripoli Level 1 Certification Build

Apogee Peregrine dual deployment rocket • Tripoli #38105 • Estonia → Sweden

docs.title: Quick Specs
docs.text: Length 68.8" (175 cm) Diameter 4.0" (98mm) Weight ~5+ lbs (~2.3 kg) Motor H128W (29mm) Recovery Dual deployment

docs.title: Launch Plan
docs.text: Date 24 Jan 2026 Backup 25 Jan 2026 Location Långtora, Sweden Club SMRK

docs.title: Status
docs.text:
Build in Progress

Tripoli membership: Active Cert level: 0 → L1 attempt

docs.title: Documentation Purpose
docs.text:
This site documents everything for my L1 certification attempt:

  1. CRO Review — Calculations and formulas for verification
  2. Build Evidence — Photo documentation of construction quality
  3. Decision Record — Reasoning behind technical choices

docs.title: Sections
docs.text: Section Description Certification Tripoli membership, L1 requirements Specifications Detailed rocket specs and kit contents Construction Build progress and techniques Calculations Stability, ejection charges, vent holes Simulations OpenRocket files and predictions Motor Selection H128W specs and safety data Flight Pre-flight checklist and log Photos Build and flight photography Decisions Key technical decisions

docs.title: L1 Requirements
docs.text:
Per Tripoli certification standards:

  • [x] Tripoli membership (Senior, insured)
  • [x] H or I class motor selected
  • [x] Rocket built by flyer
  • [ ] Successful flight with recovery
  • [ ] Witnessed by TAP/Prefect

Tõnu Samuel • Software engineer • Tallinn, Estonia Build: 77321a2 (2026-01-21)

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The Apogee Peregrine is designed for dual-deployment but can be flown in simplified configuration. This project uses two configurations:

Level Configuration Recovery Rocket Length L1 Minimal Motor ejection 126 cm L2 Full Electronic dual-deploy 175 cm

docs.title: L1 Certification Configuration
docs.text: Goal: Simple, reliable certification flight

docs.title: Hardware
docs.text:
• Shortened airframe (no e-bay section)
  • Single 48" main parachute
  • Motor ejection delay (no electronics)
  • Nose ballast for stability (~300-600g epoxy)

docs.title: Recovery Sequence
docs.text:
1. Motor burns out
  2. Delay charge burns (selected delay time)
  3. Ejection charge fires
  4. Nose cone separates, main chute deploys
  5. Rocket descends under single parachute

docs.title: Why This Configuration
docs.text:
• Fewer failure modes
  • No electronics to malfunction
  • Traditional L1 approach
  • Proves basic HPR competency

docs.title: Stability Challenge
docs.text: Removing e-bay section moves CP forward → rocket becomes unstable without nose ballast. See OpenRocket Analysis.

docs.title: L2 Certification Configuration
docs.text: Goal: Demonstrate dual-deployment competency

docs.title: Hardware
docs.text:
• Full airframe with electronics bay
  • CATS Vega flight computer
  • 18" drogue parachute (upper section)
  • 48" main parachute (lower section)
  • Redundant deployment charges

docs.title: Recovery Sequence
docs.text:
1. Motor burns out
  2. Rocket coasts to apogee
  3. Apogee: Flight computer fires drogue charge
  4. Drogue deploys, fast descent (~15-20 m/s)
  5. ~300m AGL: Flight computer fires main charge
  6. Main chute deploys, slow descent (~5 m/s)
  7. Rocket lands close to pad

docs.title: Why Dual Deployment
docs.text:
• Smaller landing footprint
  • Reduced wind drift
  • Required skill for L2 certification
  • What Peregrine is designed for

docs.title: Component Summary
docs.text: Component L1 Config L2 Config Body tube Shortened Full length Electronics bay ❌ Removed ✓ Installed CATS Vega ❌ Not used ✓ Controls deployment Drogue chute ❌ None ✓ 18" at apogee Main chute ✓ 48" ✓ 48" at 300m Deployment Motor delay Electronic Nose ballast ✓ Required Optional

docs.title: Upgrade Path
docs.text:
After L1 certification:

  1. Re-install electronics bay section
  2. Install CATS Vega on e-bay sled
  3. Wire pyro channels to deployment charges
  4. Add drogue parachute to upper section
  5. Configure flight computer events
  6. Test deployment on ground
  7. Fly L2 certification

docs.title: Flight Parameters
docs.text:
Parameter L1 Config L2 Config Rocket mass (no motor) ~2100g* ~1900g Length 126 cm 175 cm Stability ~1.0 cal* 3.69 cal Motor H128W H or I class Expected altitude ~235m ~400-600m

*With nose ballast

docs.title: Kit Purchase
docs.text: Purchased from Sierra Fox Hobbies (Italy) - listed as L2 kit but also L1 capable (flies on H motors). Was the only kit in stock from their HPR selection.

docs.title: Community Resources and discussions related to the Apogee Peregrine.
Build Threads
docs.text:
• Apogee Peregrine Build - Wally Ferrer (Feb 2021)
    • Detailed photo documentation of complete build
    • Tips: CA glue on tube edges, Kevlar string method for centering ring removal
    • Rocketpoxy fillet technique with fondant ball
    • Badass Rocketry fin guides mentioned

docs.title: Technical Discussions
docs.text:
• Trying to find an OpenRocket file for the Apogee Peregrine - laxmax51 (May 2021)

    • Discussion about importing RockSim .rkt files into OpenRocket
    • Key tip: OpenRocket can open RockSim .rkt files directly, then save as .ork
    • Note: Fancy fin shapes may not import perfectly

  • Stability measurement as a caliber or as a percentage - MetricRocketeer (Jan 2023)

    • Discusses caliber vs percentage stability display in OpenRocket
    • Contains Peregrine.ork file shared by user
    • Explains apparent CP/CG calculation discrepancies are due to OpenRocket rounding display values
    • Actual values: diameter 10.16cm (not 10.2cm), CG 113.79cm, CP 130.25cm

OpenRocket Rounding

OpenRocket displays rounded values but calculates with full precision. This explains why manual calculations from displayed values may not match the stability shown.

RockSim to OpenRocket

OpenRocket is free open-source software that can import RockSim .rkt files directly. Apogee provides RockSim files for their kits - these can be opened in OpenRocket and saved as .ork files. Fin shapes may need minor cleanup after import.

Spec Value Diameter 29mm Total Impulse 172.9 Ns Avg Thrust 128 N Burn Time 1.3 s Propellant White Lightning Case RMS-29/180 Total Mass 215 g Propellant Mass 93.6 g

Classifications

  • Motor class: H (rocketry, based on total impulse 160-320 Ns)
  • EU Pyrotechnics: P2 (requires specialist knowledge)

docs.title: Black Powder Charge Formula
docs.text:
The standard formula for calculating black powder ejection charge:

\[m_{BP} = \frac{\Delta P \cdot V \cdot C}{R \cdot T}\]

Simplified practical formula:

\[m_{BP} (grams) = \frac{D^2 \cdot L}{2270}\]

Where:

  • \(D\) = Tube inside diameter (inches)
  • \(L\) = Bay length (inches)

Safety Factor

Add 10-20% to calculated charge for reliable deployment.

docs.title: Known Values
docs.text: Parameter Value Body Tube ID ~3.9" (actual ID of 98mm tube) Pressure 15 psi (typical)

docs.title: Drogue Bay (Forward)
docs.text:
To be measured during build

Parameter Value Length TBD inches Volume TBD in³ BP Charge TBD grams

docs.title: Main Bay (Aft)
docs.text:
To be measured during build

Parameter Value Length TBD inches Volume TBD in³ BP Charge TBD grams

docs.title: RockSim Calculation
docs.text:
RockSim includes a built-in ejection charge calculator:

  1. Open Peregrine design file
  2. Go to Simulation menu
  3. Select "Ejection Charge Calculator"
  4. Enter bay dimensions
  5. Get recommended charge size

docs.title: Ground Test Procedure
docs.text:
Always Ground Test

Never fly without ground testing ejection charges!

docs.title: Test Procedure
docs.text:
1. Assemble rocket without motor
  2. Load recovery gear as for flight
  3. Install e-match with calculated charge
  4. Secure rocket horizontally
  5. Clear area and fire charge
  6. Verify clean separation and chute deployment

docs.title: Test Criteria
docs.text:
• [ ] Clean separation
  • [ ] All sections stay connected via shock cord
  • [ ] Parachute(s) fully deploy
  • [ ] No damage to components
  • [ ] Adequate force (increase charge if weak)

docs.title: Alternative: CO2 Ejection
docs.text:
Apogee offers a CO2 ejection system:

  • No black powder required
  • Peregrine Starter Kit includes:
  • 4x 8-gram cartridges
  • 4x 12-gram cartridges
  • Hardware for 2 systems

docs.text:
To be filled after bay measurements

Bay Primary Backup (+15%) Drogue TBD g TBD g Main TBD g TBD g

docs.title: L1 Weight Budget and Ballast Calculations
Reload Specifications (from ThrustCurve)
docs.text: Parameter Value Notes Designation H128W White Lightning propellant Motor Type Reload Requires RMS-29/180 casing Diameter 29 mm Needs 29→38mm adapter Length 194 mm Total Weight 206 g Complete loaded motor Propellant Weight 94 g Burns during flight Average Thrust 128.0 N Max Thrust 168.7 N Total Impulse 172.9 N·s 95% H-class Burn Time 1.3 s Delay 14 s adjustable Drill to desired delay

docs.title: Weight Breakdown
docs.text: Component Weight Notes Propellant grains 94 g Consumed during burn Nozzle, liner, delay, seals ~112 g Reload kit non-propellant Reload kit total 206 g As packaged

docs.title: RMS-29/180 Hardware
docs.text:
Component Approx Weight Notes Aluminum casing (tube) ~60 g 29mm × ~180mm Forward closure ~25 g Aft closure ~25 g Hardware set total ~110 g Reusable

Weight Clarification

ThrustCurve's "Total Weight: 206g" is the complete assembled motor (casing + reload). This is what goes in the rocket.

Post-burn motor weight: 206g - 94g = 112g

docs.title: Measured Weights
docs.text: Item Mass Method Rocket ready to fly (no motor) 1460 g Kitchen scale, includes: - Airframe (shortened L1 config) - Nose cone - Fins - Motor mount - 48" main parachute (packed) - Shock cord - Nomex protector - Rail buttons - 29→38mm motor adapter

docs.title: Motor Weight
docs.text: Item Mass H128W complete (pre-burn) 206 g H128W post-burn (casing + hardware) 112 g

docs.title: Pre-Flight Weight (No Ballast)
docs.text: \[W_{rocket} + W_{motor} = 1460g + 206g = 1666g = \mathbf{1.67\ kg}\]

docs.title: Requirement
docs.text:
Tripoli RSO (Range Safety Officer) requires:

\[\frac{\text{Average Thrust}}{\text{Liftoff Weight}} \geq 5:1\]

This ensures adequate velocity off the launch rail for stable flight.

docs.title: Current Status
docs.text: Parameter Value Status Current liftoff weight 1.67 kg ✓ Under limit Maximum allowed 2.61 kg Available margin 0.94 kg Room for ballast

docs.title: Flight Altitude Concern
docs.text:
Lighter rocket = higher altitude = longer recovery walk.

For a certification flight:

  • Want predictable, moderate altitude
  • Want to see the rocket throughout flight
  • Want quick recovery (less walking)
  • Want to stay well within field boundaries

docs.title: Target Weight
docs.text:
To fly conservatively low:

\[W_{target} \approx 2.5\ kg\]

This gives:

  • Thrust-to-weight ratio: \(\frac{128}{2.5 \times 9.81} = 5.2:1\) ✓
  • Lower apogee than minimum weight config
  • Still meets 5:1 requirement

docs.title: Required Ballast Mass
docs.text: \[W_{ballast} = W_{target} - W_{rocket} - W_{motor}$$ $$W_{ballast} = 2500g - 1460g - 206g = \mathbf{834g}\]

docs.title: Ballast Options
docs.text: Material Density Volume for 834g Lead shot 11.3 g/cm³ 74 cm³ Steel shot 7.8 g/cm³ 107 cm³ Sand 1.6 g/cm³ 521 cm³ Steel bolts/nuts 7.8 g/cm³ 107 cm³

docs.title: Ballast Placement
docs.text:
CG/CP Impact

Ballast location affects Center of Gravity!

  • Nose ballast: moves CG forward → more stable
  • Tail ballast: moves CG aft → less stable

Recommendation: Place ballast in or near nose cone to maintain/increase stability margin.

See Stability Calculations for CG/CP analysis with ballast.

docs.title: Weight Summary Table
docs.text: Configuration Pre-Flight Post-Burn Rocket (no motor, no ballast) 1460 g 1460 g + Motor (H128W) +206 g +112 g Minimum config 1666 g 1572 g + Ballast (target) +834 g +834 g With ballast 2500 g 2406 g

docs.title: OpenRocket Model vs Reality
docs.text:
Source Mass (no motor) OpenRocket model 1096 g Actual rocket 1460 g Difference +364 g

The difference is from epoxy, paint, and hardware not fully accounted for in the model.

L1 Config Stability Warning

OpenRocket shows the L1 configuration has negative stability (-0.191 cal) with model mass.

CP (90.8 cm) is forward of CG (92.7 cm) - rocket would tumble!

Nose ballast is mandatory, not optional.

See OpenRocket Simulations for full analysis.

docs.title: Action Items
docs.text:
• [ ] Verify rocket weight measurement (re-weigh)
  • [ ] Confirm motor weight when received
  • [ ] Update OpenRocket with actual 1460g mass
  • [ ] Add nose ballast to achieve positive stability
  • [ ] Calculate required ballast for ≥1.5 caliber stability
  • [ ] Run flight sim to verify stability throughout flight
  • [ ] Source appropriate ballast material (lead shot recommended)

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• ThrustCurve H128W Data
  • Tripoli Safety Code
  • L1 Configuration Decision

docs.title: Why It Matters
docs.text:
The rocket must achieve sufficient velocity before leaving the launch rail for the fins to provide aerodynamic stability. Below this velocity, the rocket may:

  • Weathercock into wind
  • Fly unstable trajectory
  • Tip over on the pad

docs.title: Minimum Rail Exit Velocity
docs.text:
Rule of Thumb

Minimum rail exit velocity: 50 ft/s (15 m/s)

Recommended: 60-80 ft/s for margin of safety

docs.title: Physics
docs.text:
Rail exit velocity depends on:

\[V_{exit} = \sqrt{V_0^2 + 2 \cdot a_{avg} \cdot L_{rail}}\]

Where:

  • \(V_0\) = Initial velocity (0 for standing start)
  • \(a_{avg}\) = Average acceleration during rail travel
  • \(L_{rail}\) = Effective rail length

Simplified:

\[V_{exit} = \sqrt{\frac{2 \cdot F_{avg} \cdot L_{rail}}{m}}\]

Where:

  • \(F_{avg}\) = Average thrust force (N)
  • \(m\) = Liftoff mass (kg)

docs.title: Minimum Rail Length
docs.text:
Rearranging for rail length:

\[L_{rail} = \frac{m \cdot V_{exit}^2}{2 \cdot F_{avg}}\]

docs.title: Estimated Values
docs.text: Parameter Value Liftoff Mass ~6 lbs (~2.7 kg) with H motor Target Exit Velocity 60 ft/s (18 m/s)

docs.title: Example: AeroTech H180W
docs.text:
Parameter Value Average Thrust 180 N (40 lbf) Liftoff Mass ~2.7 kg Min Rail Length Calculate below \[L_{rail} = \frac{2.7 \cdot 18^2}{2 \cdot 180} = \frac{874.8}{360} = 2.4 m \approx 8 ft\]

Rail Length

An 8-foot (2.4m) rail should provide adequate exit velocity for the Peregrine on H motors.

Standard high-power rail lengths: - 6 ft (1.8m) - marginal for heavy rockets - 8 ft (2.4m) - good for most HPR - 10 ft (3m) - excellent margin

docs.title: Simulation Verification
docs.text:
OpenRocket/RockSim calculate rail exit velocity:

Insert simulation results here

Motor Rail Length Exit Velocity Status H180W 6 ft TBD TBD H180W 8 ft TBD TBD H100W 8 ft TBD TBD

docs.title: Wind Considerations
docs.text:
In windy conditions:

  • Higher exit velocity needed
  • Consider longer rail
  • Or postpone launch if marginal

Rule: Add 10 ft/s to minimum for each 10 mph wind.

docs.title: Stability Criteria
docs.text:
For a stable rocket flight:

\[\text{Stability Margin} = \frac{X_{CP} - X_{CG}}{d} \geq 1.0\]

Where:

  • \(X_{CP}\) = Center of Pressure location (from nose tip)
  • \(X_{CG}\) = Center of Gravity location (from nose tip)
  • \(d\) = Body tube diameter (caliber)

Target

CG should be 1 to 2 calibers ahead of CP

  • Less than 1 caliber: marginally stable
  • More than 2 calibers: will weathercock

docs.title: Peregrine Stability
docs.text:
With 4" diameter body:

  • 1 caliber = 4 inches
  • Target: CG 4-8" ahead of CP
Configuration CG CP Margin Status To be filled from OpenRocket

docs.title: Method: Balance Point
docs.text:
1. Fully load rocket (motor, recovery, electronics)
  2. Balance on finger or rod
  3. Mark balance point
  4. Measure from nose tip

docs.title: Weight Considerations
docs.text: Item Approx Weight Notes Airframe (empty) ~5 lbs As built Altimeter 0.5-2 oz Varies by model Motor (H180) ~8 oz Loaded Recovery gear ~4 oz Packed

docs.title: Barrowman Equations
docs.text:
Classic analytical method for CP location. Implemented in:

  • RockSim
  • OpenRocket

docs.title: Cardboard Cutout Method
docs.text:
Simple physical approximation:

  1. Draw rocket profile on cardboard
  2. Cut out profile
  3. Balance cutout
  4. Balance point ≈ CP

Conservative Method

Cardboard cutout gives a conservative estimate. Actual CP is usually further aft.

docs.title: Dynamic Stability
docs.text:
Beyond static stability, dynamic factors include:

  • Launch velocity (affects weathercocking)
  • Wind conditions
  • Fin size and shape
  • Mass distribution

RockSim/OpenRocket simulate these factors.

docs.title: Simulation Results
docs.text:
Insert OpenRocket stability analysis here

See OpenRocket Results for full simulation data.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
Vent holes (static ports) allow the altimeter to sense ambient air pressure during flight. Without proper venting, pressure differentials can cause:

  • Inaccurate altitude readings
  • Premature or delayed deployment
  • Structural stress on airframe

docs.title: Vent Hole Formula
docs.text:
Minimum vent hole area:

\[A_{vent} = \frac{A_{tube} \cdot V_{descent}}{V_{sound}} \cdot N\]

Simplified rule of thumb:

\[A_{vent} \geq \frac{V_{bay}}{100}\]

Where:

  • \(A_{vent}\) = Total vent area (in²)
  • \(V_{bay}\) = Bay internal volume (in³)

docs.title: Number of Holes
docs.text:
• Minimum: 2 holes (180° apart)
  • Recommended: 3-4 holes (evenly spaced)
  • Prevents asymmetric pressure effects

docs.title: Hole Size
docs.text:
Common sizes for 4" diameter rockets:

Hole Diameter Area per Hole 4 Holes Total 1/8" (3mm) 0.012 in² 0.049 in² 3/16" (5mm) 0.028 in² 0.110 in² 1/4" (6mm) 0.049 in² 0.196 in²

docs.title: Placement
docs.text:
Hole Location

  • Place in e-bay coupler section
  • Position near altimeter sensor
  • Avoid direct line to ejection charge
  • Not too close to tube joints

docs.title: Peregrine Vent Holes
docs.text:
To be determined during build

Parameter Value E-bay length TBD inches Number of holes TBD Hole diameter TBD Total vent area TBD in²

docs.title: Breather Holes vs Static Ports
docs.text:
• Static Ports: For altimeter pressure sensing
  • Breather Holes: For recovery bay equalization

Both may be needed in different locations.

docs.title: Switch Hole
docs.text:
If using external arming switch:

  • Switch mounting hole also provides venting
  • Account for this area in calculations
  • Use switch band for clean installation

docs.title: Testing
docs.text:
Verify altimeter function after drilling:

  1. Power on altimeter
  2. Seal one end of e-bay
  3. Gently blow into/suck on other end
  4. Altimeter should show altitude change
  5. Altitude should return to zero when released

docs.title: Tripoli Membership
docs.text: Field Value Organization Tripoli Rocketry Association Member Number 38105 Status Sr. Member - Insured Current Cert Level 0 Expires November 2026

docs.title: L1 Requirements
docs.text:
Per Tripoli certification standards:

  • Successfully fly and recover a rocket using an H or I motor
  • Witnessed by a Tripoli Prefect or TAP member
  • Rocket must be built by the flyer (kits allowed)
  • Safe flight with successful recovery

docs.text: Pending - See Flight Log

docs.text:
• Location: Sweden (see Why Sweden)
  • Rocket: Apogee Peregrine
  • Motor: AeroTech H128W (see Motor Procurement)

docs.title: Post-Certification
docs.text:
After L1, eligible for:

  • L2 certification (J, K, L motors)
  • Eventually L3 (M+ motors)

docs.title: Build Log
docs.text: This page documents the construction progress of my Apogee Peregrine.

docs.title: Build Status
docs.text:
Current Phase

Motor mount and fin assembly complete. Electronics bay in progress.

docs.title: Planned Build Sequence
docs.text:
Following Apogee's recommended construction order:

  1. Motor Mount Assembly

    • Mark motor tube
    • Attach centering rings
    • Install Kevlar shock cord anchor
    • Add thrust block (if using short motors)

  2. Fin Installation

    • Prepare fin slots in body tube
    • Test fit fins
    • Tack with CA glue
    • Internal fillets with epoxy
    • External fillets

  3. Electronics Bay

    • Sand bulkhead edges
    • Install stop rings
    • Glue threaded rod alignment rails
    • Assemble sled
    • Install switch band
    • Mount eyebolts

  4. Airframe Assembly

    • Join body tube sections with couplers
    • Install motor mount
    • Add rail buttons

  5. Recovery System

    • Attach shock cords
    • Install quick links
    • Attach chute protectors

  6. Finishing

    • Fill spirals (if desired)
    • Prime
    • Paint
    • Apply decals

docs.title: 2025-12-11: Kit Received
docs.text:
Kit acquisition timeline:

Date Event 28 Nov 2025 Ordered from Sierra Fox Hobbies (Italy) 2 Dec 2025 Shipped via DHL 5 Dec 2025 Milan, Italy 9 Dec 2025 Poznan, Poland 11 Dec 2025 Delivered to Tallinn, Estonia

DHL Tracking: 3425738702

Photos:

Kit packaging photos in Photo Gallery.

docs.title: 2025-12-XX: Motor Mount & Fin Assembly
docs.text:
Duration: ~4 days (24-hour epoxy cure cycles)

Work completed:

  • Motor mount assembly with centering rings
  • Through-the-wall (TTW) fin installation
  • 6-point epoxy attachment for maximum strength

Method:

Used 1-hour working time epoxy with 24-hour cure. Due to liquid epoxy leaking through centering ring holes, each side was cured separately:

Day Work 1 Bottom centering ring bonds 2 Top centering ring bonds 3 Internal fin fillets (to motor mount) 4 External fin fillets (to airframe)

Notes:

The liquid epoxy was challenging - it kept seeping through small holes. Solution was to position the rocket so gravity kept epoxy at the joint being cured, then flip for opposite side. Result is very strong integrated fin can.

See Motor Mount and Fins for detailed documentation.

Photos:

To be added - see Issue #8

Additional build log entries will be added as construction progresses

docs.title: E-Bay Specifications
docs.text: Component Description Diameter 98mm (4") Design Single threaded rod (lighter than dual) Access Wing nut removal, sled slides out Sled Glued to one bulkhead

docs.title: Design Advantages
docs.text:
Apogee's e-bay design features:

  • Fewer parts = lighter weight
  • Faster field setup
  • Shorter pre-flight checklist
  • Easy electronics access

docs.title: 1. Bulkhead Preparation
docs.text:
• Sand edges of plywood bulkheads
  • Remove any laser char

docs.title: 2. Stop Rings
docs.text:
• Glue stop rings to inner tube
  • These position the sled correctly

docs.title: 3. Threaded Rod Rails
docs.text:
• Glue alignment rails for threaded rod
  • Ensures straight rod path

docs.title: 4. Sled Assembly
docs.text:
• Glue sled plate to bulkhead with single slot
  • Add internal fillets for strength
  • Pre-drill holes for altimeter mounting

docs.title: 5. Switch Band
docs.text:
• Install switch band on coupler tube
  • May need to peel inner paper layer if tight fit
  • Glue centered on coupler

docs.title: 6. Eyebolt Installation
docs.text:
• Install eyebolts on both bulkheads
  • These attach to shock cords

docs.title: 7. Final Assembly
docs.text:
• Insert sled through coupler
  • Secure with washer and wing nut
  • Test fit in airframe

docs.title: Electronics Mounting
docs.text:
Altimeter Installation

The sled provides mounting holes for:

  • Dual deployment altimeter
  • GPS tracker
  • Wiring routing between sides

docs.title: Recommended Altimeters
docs.text:
• Featherweight Blue Jay (compact, affordable)
  • Missileworks RRC3
  • Eggtimer Quantum
  • PerfectFlite StratoLogger

docs.title: Wiring Considerations
docs.text:
• Route wires through sled holes
  • Keep wiring short to reduce snag risk
  • Use CAT5 cable for power runs
  • Strategic hot glue to prevent vibration issues

docs.title: Build Photos
docs.text: Photos to be added during construction

docs.title: Fin Specifications
docs.text: Property Value Quantity 3 Material Birch plywood Profile Swept-back curved Attachment Through-the-wall (TTW) Extends Below Tube Yes

docs.title: Unique Fin Design
docs.text:
The Peregrine's fins are distinctive:

  • Curved leading edge (reminiscent of 1950s sci-fi rockets)
  • Extend below the body tube base
  • Interlocking tab structure for alignment
  • Large surface area for stability

docs.title: 6-Point Attachment Method
docs.text:
The fins use Through-The-Wall (TTW) construction with 6-point epoxy attachment for maximum strength:

                    AIRFRAME (body tube)
                          │
    ┌─────────────────────┼─────────────────────┐
    │                     │                     │
    │  ④ External     ┌───┴───┐    ④ External  │
    │     Fillet      │       │       Fillet    │
    │                 │  FIN  │                 │
    │  ③ Internal     │       │    ③ Internal  │
    │     Fillet      └───┬───┘       Fillet    │
    │                     │                     │
    └─────────────────────┼─────────────────────┘
                          │
    ┌─────────────────────┼─────────────────────┐
    │                     │                     │
    │  ② Outside      ┌───┴───┐    ② Outside   │
    │     Fillet      │       │       Fillet    │
    │                 │  FIN  │                 │
    │  ① Inside       │ ROOT  │    ① Inside    │
    │     Fillet      └───┬───┘       Fillet    │
    │                     │                     │
    └─────────────────────┴─────────────────────┘
                    MOTOR MOUNT TUBE

docs.title: The 6 Attachment Points
docs.text:
Point Location Purpose ① Fin root to motor mount (inside) Primary structural bond ② Fin root to motor mount (outside) Reinforces motor mount bond ③ Fin root to airframe (internal fillet) Bonds fin to body tube interior ④ Fin root to airframe (external fillet) Visible fillet, aerodynamic ⑤ Centering ring to airframe Locks motor mount in place ⑥ Centering ring to motor tube Completes the rigid structure

This creates an extremely strong integrated structure where the fins, motor mount, and airframe become a single rigid unit.

docs.title: 1. Preparation
docs.text:
• Sand fin edges lightly
  • Test fit in body tube slots
  • Ensure interlocking structure aligns properly

docs.title: 2. Tacking
docs.text:
• Use thick CA to tack fins in position
  • Verify alignment with fin guide or laser level
  • Check all fins are parallel to centerline

docs.title: 3. Internal Fillets (Points ①, ③)
docs.text:
• Apply epoxy inside motor mount area
  • Use the Kevlar pull-out technique for rear ring access
  • Ensure contact with motor tube and centering rings
  • Cure 24 hours before proceeding

docs.title: 4. External Fillets (Points ②, ④)
docs.text:
• Mix epoxy (1-hour working time used)
  • Apply fillet material to external joints
  • Use popsicle stick to form smooth concave shape
  • Cure 24 hours

docs.title: Epoxy Application
docs.text:
Liquid Epoxy Challenge

1-hour epoxy was quite liquid and leaked through small gaps in centering rings. Each side required separate 24-hour cure cycles:

  • Position rocket so epoxy pools at joint, not leaks away
  • Flip and repeat for opposite side
  • Total assembly time: ~4 days

docs.title: Result
docs.text: The 6-point TTW attachment creates a very rigid fin can assembly. Fins cannot flex or rotate relative to motor mount or airframe.

docs.title: Fin Flutter Considerations
docs.text:
At expected velocities (under Mach 0.5), fin flutter is not a concern for:

  • Birch plywood construction
  • Proper fillet application
  • Normal H/I motor flights

docs.title: Build Photos
docs.text: Photos to be added - see Issue #8

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text: Component Value Motor Tube ID 38mm Motor Tube Length 11" (28 cm) Centering Rings Plywood, 38mm to 98mm

docs.title: Motor Retention Options
docs.text: The kit does NOT include motor retention. Options:

docs.title: Option 1: AeroPack Retainer (Recommended)
docs.text:
• AeroPack 38L for LOC-style paper tubes (OD 1.630")
  • Provides professional appearance
  • Easy motor changes
  • Epoxy to aft centering ring

docs.title: Option 2: Fins & Fire Retainer
docs.text:
• Alternative to AeroPack
  • Similar functionality

docs.title: Option 3: Masking Tape (Traditional)
docs.text:
• Wrap tape around motor at tube exit
  • Simple and effective
  • Must re-tape each flight

docs.title: Shock Cord Attachment
docs.text:
The motor mount includes a Kevlar cord anchor:

  1. Thread Kevlar through centering ring holes
  2. Secure with epoxy
  3. Allows rear centering ring to be pulled out for internal fillet access

docs.title: Long Motor Accommodation
docs.text:
Motor Length

The motor tube is 11" long. For motors longer than the tube:

  • Remove thrust block
  • Motor will project into parachute bay
  • Verify adequate space for recovery gear

docs.title: Epoxy Selection
docs.text:
Used 1-hour epoxy (working time) with 24-hour cure.

Epoxy Viscosity Issue

The epoxy was quite liquid, which caused it to leak through small holes in the centering rings. This required careful orientation during curing.

docs.title: Curing Process
docs.text:
Due to liquid epoxy leaking, each side was cured separately:

  1. Day 1: Motor mount positioned upright, epoxy applied to bottom centering ring area
  2. Day 2: Flipped, epoxy applied to top centering ring area
  3. Day 3: Internal fin fillets
  4. Day 4: External fin fillets

Total cure time: ~4 days for complete assembly.

docs.title: Lessons Learned
docs.text:
• Thicker epoxy (Rocketpoxy or thickened with microballoons) would reduce leakage
  • Pre-sealing centering ring holes with thin CA can help
  • Patience with 24-hour cure cycles results in stronger bonds

docs.title: Build Photos
docs.text: Photos to be added - see Issue #8

docs.title: Dual Deployment Overview
docs.text:
flowchart TD
    A[Launch] --> B[Motor Burnout]
    B --> C[Coast to Apogee]
    C --> D[Altimeter Fires Drogue Charge]
    D --> E[Drogue Deploys - Fast Descent]
    E --> F[Reach Main Deploy Altitude]
    F --> G[Altimeter Fires Main Charge]
    G --> H[Main Deploys - Slow Descent]
    H --> I[Landing]

docs.title: Recovery Components
docs.text: Component Size Location Drogue Parachute 18" (45 cm) Forward bay (nose to e-bay) Main Parachute 48" (122 cm) Aft bay (e-bay to fins) Chute Protectors 12" Nomex x2 One per bay Shock Cord (drogue) Long, orange tubular nylon Forward Shock Cord (main) Short, orange tubular nylon Aft

docs.title: Shock Cord Assignment
docs.text:
Cord Lengths

Per Apogee instructions:

  • Shorter cord goes in forward/drogue section
  • Longer cord goes with motor mount (discovered by reading full instructions)

docs.title: Chute Protector Attachment
docs.text:
• Attach close to tube exits
  • Allow enough slack for chute to fully clear
  • Some builders add one protector-width spacing

docs.title: Parachute Attachment
docs.text:
Use quick links for easy field changes:

Nose Cone Loop ─── Quick Link ─── Shock Cord ─── Quick Link ─── Drogue Chute
                                      │
                                E-Bay Eyebolt

docs.title: Single Deploy Configuration
docs.text:
For L1 certification (recommended):

  1. Place main parachute in aft bay
  2. Use motor ejection charge
  3. Secure nose cone to upper tube (tape or plastic rivets)
  4. Leave drogue removed or use as backup

Shear Pins

For dual deploy after certification:

  • Use metal screws for single deploy (nose stays attached)
  • Switch to nylon shear pins for dual deploy
  • 2-3 shear pins typically sufficient for Peregrine

docs.title: Descent Rate Calculations
docs.text:
See Ejection Charges for sizing.

Target descent rates:

Phase Target Rate Drogue 50-75 ft/s (fast but controlled) Main 15-20 ft/s (soft landing)

docs.title: Build Photos
docs.text: Photos to be added during construction

docs.title: Decision Log
docs.text: This section documents key decisions made during the L1 certification journey, including reasoning and constraints considered.

docs.title: Entries
docs.text:
• L1 Configuration - Minimal config for certification flight
  • Why Sweden - Choosing certification location
  • Motor Procurement - How to obtain motors legally
  • Motor Retainer - 3D printed ASA retainer
  • Motor Adapter - 38mm to 29mm clamshell adapter (PETG)
  • Rail Guides - Kit buttons + 3D printed backup
  • Color and Purpose - Why blue, why this rocket
  • Flight Computer - CATS Vega vs motor delay

docs.title: Decision
docs.text: Blue rocket

docs.title: The Real Why
docs.text: This rocket isn't just about L1 certification.

docs.title: Teaching Engineering to Children
docs.text: From five children, two are underage daughters: Liza (5) and Elsa (2). Teaching complicated topics to young children is difficult unless they're naturally interested.

docs.title: Sipsik Connection
docs.text:
In Estonia there's a beloved cartoon character Sipsik - a blue rag doll comfort toy belonging to a girl named Anu. Her older brother Mart builds a rocket from a cardboard box, and they throw it up hoping Sipsik will fly to the moon. In the cartoon, Sipsik actually reaches the moon and returns (probably only in Anu's dreams, but this detail doesn't matter to children).

This cartoon inspires Estonian girls to build rockets from cardboard boxes.

docs.title: The Opportunity
docs.text:
The moment exists now to teach the girls how we're actually going to send her Sipsik to the moon. A real rocket, real engineering, real flight - connected to something they already love and understand.

The blue color matches Sipsik's colors.

docs.title: Actual Sipsik Payload
docs.text:
Plan is to stuff a Sipsik toy into the rocket body for actual flight.

Open Problem

How to package Sipsik safely:

  • Protect from ejection charge heat/flames
  • Ensure recovery (not lost on ejection)
  • Not interfere with parachute deployment

docs.title: Outcome
docs.text:
The rocket serves dual purpose:

  1. Technical: Tripoli L1 certification
  2. Educational: Hands-on engineering lesson for daughters through familiar cultural connection

docs.title: Context
docs.text: Dual deployment requires electronic altimeter to fire ejection charges at correct altitudes. Alternative is single deployment using motor delay.

docs.title: Equipment Ordered
docs.text:
• CATS Vega - Flight computer
  • CATS Ground Station - Telemetry receiver

docs.title: Why CATS
docs.text: Fully Open Source - hardware designs in Altium format. This fits my background perfectly. Could copy designs and order own PCBs, but purchased to support the project.

docs.title: Shipping Status
docs.text:
Package shipping from Switzerland, may arrive too late for 24 Jan launch.

  • Swiss Post tracking
  • Omniva tracking (Estonia)

docs.title: Option A: Motor Delay (Simple)
docs.text:
Single chute deployment using motor ejection delay. Often recommended for L1 certification to keep it failproof.

Pros:

  • Simpler, fewer failure modes
  • Traditional L1 approach
  • No electronics dependency

docs.title: Option B: Electronic Dual Deployment
docs.text:
Use CATS Vega for drogue at apogee, main at lower altitude.

Pros:

  • Closer-to-pad recovery (what Peregrine is designed for)
  • Decades of sensor/actuator experience gives me an edge
  • Arguably safer for someone with electronics background

Cons:

  • More complexity for certification flight
  • Equipment may not arrive in time

docs.title: Outcome
docs.text:
If CATS arrives in time → likely go electronic dual deployment

If not → motor delay single deployment

docs.title: Decision
docs.text: Fly the certification flight in minimal L1 configuration rather than full dual-deployment setup.

docs.title: Full L2 Configuration (IMG_6434)
docs.text:
• Main body tube
  • Electronics bay (e-bay) with altimeter
  • Coupler tube between e-bay and nose cone
  • Nose cone
  • 18" drogue parachute (upper section)
  • 48" main parachute (lower section)
  • Dual deployment (altimeter-controlled)

docs.title: Minimal L1 Configuration (IMG_7824)
docs.text:
• Main body tube (shortened - no e-bay section)
  • Nose cone attached directly to body tube
  • 48" main parachute only
  • Motor ejection charge deployment (no electronics)

docs.title: Removed Components
docs.text:
Component Weight Estimate Reason Electronics bay tube ~100g Not needed for motor ejection E-bay bulkheads, sled, hardware ~150g No altimeter deployment 18" drogue parachute ~30g Single deployment only Coupler tube (e-bay to nose) ~80g Shorter rocket Altimeter ~50g Motor ejection is sufficient

Total removed: ~400g estimated

docs.title: Simplicity
docs.text:
L1 certification demonstrates basic HPR competency. Adding dual-deployment electronics introduces failure modes:

  • Altimeter malfunction
  • Wiring issues
  • Battery problems
  • Charge firing timing
  • Multiple separation events

For certification, minimize variables.

docs.title: Reliability
docs.text:
Motor ejection is proven technology:

  • No electronics to fail
  • No batteries to die
  • No wiring to disconnect
  • Single separation event

docs.title: Regulatory
docs.text: No pyrotechnic electronics to explain to Swedish authorities. Simpler = less questions.

docs.title: Reversibility
docs.text:
After L1 certification:

  • Re-install electronics bay
  • Add drogue parachute
  • Full dual-deployment for L2

All removed components are stored safely.

docs.title: Weight Impact
docs.text:
Configuration Approximate Mass Full L2 config (empty) ~1.9 kg L1 minimal (empty) ~1.46 kg L1 with motor (H128W) ~1.67 kg

The lighter rocket with H128W will fly higher than needed for a conservative certification flight. See L1 Weight Budget for ballast calculations.

docs.title: Photos
docs.text: Configuration Photo Full L2 (painted) L1 minimal (window view)

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Stability Calculations - CG/CP for L1 config
  • L1 Weight Budget - Mass budget and ballast
  • Motor Selection - H128W specifications

docs.title: Context
docs.text:
Peregrine motor mount is 38mm diameter. Selected motor (AeroTech H128W) is 29mm diameter.

Need an adapter to center the 29mm motor in the 38mm tube.

docs.title: Decision
docs.text: 3D printed clamshell adapter from Thingiverse Thing:5971997

docs.title: Implementation
docs.text: Parameter Value Design Clamshell (two halves) Material Translucent PETG Printer Bambu Lab P1S Infill TBD Layer height TBD

docs.title: Material Selection: PETG vs ASA
docs.text:
Preferred material would be ASA (better heat resistance, UV stable), but:

Printer Limitation

Bambu Lab P1S lacks chamber heating. Tall ASA prints warp and fail ("spaghetti") after reaching certain height without enclosure temperature control.

PETG characteristics:

  • Adequate temperature resistance for adapter (not in exhaust path)
  • Prints reliably without heated chamber
  • Translucent allows visual inspection of motor position
  • Sufficient strength for centering function

docs.title: Clamshell Design Benefits
docs.text:
• Two-piece design simplifies installation/removal
  • No need to slide motor through adapter
  • Can inspect motor centering before flight
  • Easy to replace if damaged

docs.title: Photos
docs.text: To be added

docs.title: Context
docs.text:
Need H-class motor for L1 certification attempt. Options:

  1. Buy in Estonia, transport to Sweden
  2. Buy locally in Sweden

docs.title: Decision
docs.text: Purchase motor locally in Sweden (H128W + 38mm→29mm adapter from Swedish Tripoli members)

docs.title: Estonian Regulatory Uncertainty
docs.text:
Estonia lacks clear framework for amateur rocketry:

  • No Tripoli prefecture or members
  • No established rocket launch sites
  • Contacted Lennuamet (aviation authority) and TTJA (consumer protection/technical safety) - neither could provide clear guidance on pyrotechnics handling

docs.title: P2 Pyrotechnics Classification
docs.text:
H-class motors (rocketry classification) are P2 category in EU pyrotechnics regulation (Directive 2013/29/EU). P2 requires "specialist knowledge" to handle.

Rules differ by country and TTJA couldn't confirm what certifications/tests would be required for legal purchase and possession in Estonia.

docs.title: Border Transport Issues
docs.text:
Even if legally obtained in Estonia:

  • Transporting pyrotechnics across borders requires paperwork
  • Each country may have different rules
  • Additional bureaucratic overhead for one-time use

docs.title: Ferry Transport Risk Assessment
docs.text:
Considered taking motor by car on Tallink ferry to Sweden:

  • Would require one-time permission from Tallink
  • From ferry operator's perspective: risk/reward doesn't make sense
  • Small theoretical incident = millions in losses
  • ~100 EUR ticket revenue not worth any risk
  • Would likely be denied

docs.title: Swedish Solution
docs.text:
Contacted Swedish Tripoli members who confirmed:

  • Can sell 1-2 AeroTech H128W motors locally
  • May have 38mm→29mm adapter available
  • No border crossing with pyrotechnics needed
  • Legal under Swedish framework

docs.title: Outcome
docs.text: Motor will be purchased at or near launch site in Sweden. Eliminates all transport and regulatory complications.

docs.title: Context
docs.text:
Kit does not include motor retention. Options:

  • AeroPack 38L Engine Retainer (commercial)
  • Fins & Fire 38mm Retainer (commercial)
  • Masking tape (traditional method)
  • 3D printed retainer

docs.title: Decision
docs.text: 3D printed retainer from Thingiverse model #6780161

docs.title: Implementation
docs.text:
• Material: ASA (weather/UV resistant, good heat tolerance)
  • Attachment: Epoxied to aft end of motor mount tube

docs.title: Reasoning
docs.text:
• Cost effective
  • Available immediately (no shipping wait)
  • ASA provides adequate heat resistance for motor exhaust
  • Can reprint if damaged

docs.title: Photos
docs.text: To be added

docs.title: Context
docs.text: Rocket needs rail guides/buttons to slide on launch rail. Kit includes rail buttons.

docs.title: Current Setup
docs.text: Kit-supplied rail buttons installed. Measure 6.2mm wide at narrowest point.

docs.title: Concern
docs.text: Unknown if kit buttons will fit the launch rail available in Sweden. Rail slot widths vary.

docs.title: Backup Plan
docs.text: 3D print rail guides from same Thingiverse source as motor retainer. Will bring printed spares to Sweden.

docs.title: Photos
docs.text: To be added

docs.title: Context
docs.text:
Estonia has no Tripoli prefecture. Closest options are:

  • Finland
  • Latvia
  • Sweden

docs.title: Decision
docs.text:
Sweden - Långtora Airfield

  • Date: Saturday, 24 January 2026
  • Backup: Sunday, 25 January 2026 (weather contingency)

docs.title: Reasoning
docs.text:
1. Personal - Daughter lives in Stockholm
  2. Practical - Discount coupons available for Tallink ferry
  3. Support - Swedish Tripoli members confirmed they can sell motors locally

docs.title: Alternatives Considered
docs.text: Finland and Latvia are geographically closer but lack the personal connections and confirmed motor availability.

docs.title: Day Before Launch
docs.text:
• [ ] Check weather forecast
  • [ ] Charge altimeter battery
  • [ ] Verify motor availability
  • [ ] Pack all equipment
  • [ ] Review simulation predictions

docs.title: Rocket Components
docs.text:
• [ ] Rocket (all sections)
  • [ ] Motor(s)
  • [ ] Motor retention hardware
  • [ ] Igniters and igniter clips
  • [ ] Recovery wadding (if using)

docs.title: Electronics
docs.text:
• [ ] Altimeter (charged)
  • [ ] Fresh batteries (spares)
  • [ ] E-matches (if dual deploy)
  • [ ] Black powder charges (measured)
  • [ ] Masking tape for charge cups

docs.title: Recovery
docs.text:
• [ ] Main parachute
  • [ ] Drogue parachute (if dual deploy)
  • [ ] Shock cords (inspect for damage)
  • [ ] Quick links
  • [ ] Chute protectors

docs.title: Tools
docs.text:
• [ ] Allen wrenches
  • [ ] Screwdrivers
  • [ ] Tape (masking, electrical)
  • [ ] Knife/scissors
  • [ ] Marker/pen

docs.title: Safety
docs.text:
• [ ] Safety glasses
  • [ ] First aid kit
  • [ ] Fire extinguisher (club usually provides)
  • [ ] Cell phone

docs.title: 1. Motor Installation
docs.text:
• [ ] Install motor in mount
  • [ ] Secure motor retention
  • [ ] Verify motor is seated correctly

docs.title: 2. Recovery Prep
docs.text:
• [ ] Fold parachute(s)
  • [ ] Attach chute protectors
  • [ ] Load recovery bays
  • [ ] Secure nose cone (tape/shear pins)

docs.title: 3. Electronics (if dual deploy)
docs.text:
• [ ] Connect e-match leads
  • [ ] Verify continuity (altimeter beeps)
  • [ ] Arm altimeter
  • [ ] Close e-bay
  • [ ] Secure rivets/shear pins

docs.title: 4. Final Checks
docs.text:
• [ ] CG location verified
  • [ ] All sections secure
  • [ ] Rail buttons/lugs clear
  • [ ] Igniter installed (last step)

docs.title: Post-Flight
docs.text:
• [ ] Photograph landing site
  • [ ] Inspect for damage
  • [ ] Download altimeter data
  • [ ] Record flight details
  • [ ] Prep for next flight or pack up

docs.title: L1 Certification Specific
docs.text:
• [ ] Notify prefect/TAP of certification attempt
  • [ ] Have membership card ready
  • [ ] Complete certification paperwork before flight
  • [ ] Witness signature after successful flight

docs.title: Flight Records
docs.text: Flight entries will be added here after each flight

docs.text:

### Results

### Notes

docs.title: Photo Gallery
docs.text: This section contains photographs documenting the build and flight of the Peregrine.

docs.title: Organization
docs.text:
Photos are organized by category:

  • kit/ - Unboxing and kit contents
  • build/ - Construction progress
  • finishing/ - Painting and decals
  • flight/ - Launch and recovery photos

docs.title: Adding Photos
docs.text:
To add photos:

  1. Add image files to appropriate subdirectory in docs/photos/
  2. Reference in markdown:
![Description](photos/category/filename.jpg)

docs.title: Kit Packaging
docs.text:
Packaging vs Website Discrepancies

See Kit Contents for documented discrepancies between packaging claims and actual specifications.

  • Skill Level: Packaging says 4, website says 3
  • Height: Packaging says "Over 65"", actual is 68.8"

docs.title: IMG_7726 - Front Package Feature List
docs.text:
Features listed on packaging:

  • Dual-Deployment recovery for closer-to-the-pad recovery
  • High-power rocket kit
  • Large and colorful vinyl decals included
  • Impressive Size: Over 65" tall and 4" in diameter
  • Two colorful nylon cloth parachutes included

Also visible: partial view of body tube with "PEREGRINE" branding.

docs.title: IMG_7727 - Motor Requirements and Altitude Table
docs.text:
Motor Requirements:

  • Requires 38mm diameter rocket motors
  • Use H, I or J power rocket motors, as well as high thrust G motors

Typical altitudes:

Motor Class Altitude Range G motors 300-500 feet (requires avg thrust ≥80N) H motors 600-1700 feet I motors 1700-3500 feet J motors 3700-6100 feet

docs.title: IMG_7728 - Required Tools and Materials
docs.text:
Required Tools and Materials:

  • Hobby Knife / Ruler / Pencil
  • Wood Glue (recommended) or White Glue
  • Liquid epoxy
  • Sand Paper 200 Grit, 400 grit and Sanding Block
  • Masking Tape / Scissors / Paper Towel
  • Wood Dowel

Optional Tools / Finishing Supplies:

  • Aluminum "Angle" to draw lines on the tube
  • Paint Supplies: Spray Paint, Brushes, etc
  • Plastic Sheet (to cover the work surface)
  • Safety Glasses (or general protection while building)
  • Super Glue (CyA Adhesive medium viscosity)
  • Wood Sealer / Sanding Sealer
  • RocketPoxy (paste-style)

docs.title: IMG_7729 - Kit Identification
docs.text:
• Kit# 04998
  • Skill Level 4
  • Model rocket kit - assembly required
  • Recommended for 18 years and older
  • Apogee Components Inc., Colorado Springs, Colorado
  • Barcode: 6 56779 04998 8
  • Face Card P/N 39101

Aft view of the booster showing:

Full aft view of the painted booster section showing:

docs.title: Kit Guidance
docs.text:
From kit packaging (IMG_7727):

  • Requires 38mm diameter rocket motors
  • Use H, I or J power motors, as well as high thrust G motors

Typical altitudes per packaging:

Motor Class Altitude Range G motors 300-500 ft (requires avg thrust ≥80N) H motors 600-1700 ft I motors 1700-3500 ft J motors 3700-6100 ft

docs.title: Selected Motor
docs.text:
AeroTech H128W-14A - purchased locally in Sweden from Tripoli members.

See Motor Procurement for why this is the only practical option.

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text: Parameter Value Diameter 29mm (reload) Total Impulse 172.9 N·s Max Thrust 168.7 N Average Thrust 128 N Burn Time 1.3 s Delay 14 s (adjustable) Propellant White Lightning (W) Motor Length 194 mm Total Mass 215 g Propellant Mass 93.6 g

docs.title: Hardware Required
docs.text:
The H128W is a reload motor requiring:

  • AeroTech 29/180 Case (PN: 60010)
  • 29mm forward closure
  • 29mm aft closure

docs.title: Adapter Required
docs.text:
Peregrine has 38mm motor mount. H128W is 29mm.

Solution: 3D printed clamshell adapter from Thingiverse Thing:5971997

Parameter Value Design Clamshell (two halves) Material Translucent PETG Printer Bambu Lab P1S

Material Choice

PETG instead of ASA because P1S lacks chamber heating. Tall ASA prints fail (spaghetti) after reaching certain height without enclosure temperature control.

docs.title: Safety
docs.text: Based on AeroTech Safety Data Sheet:

docs.title: Hazard Classification
docs.text: H128W propellant mass is 93.6g, classified as Explosive 1.3C (>62.5g propellant).

docs.title: Handling
docs.text:
• No smoking within 25 ft (7.6m)
  • Keep away from open flames and heat sources
  • Store in dry location, away from acids
  • Keep in original packaging until ready for use
  • Do not use indoors

docs.title: Combustion Products
docs.text:
White Lightning propellant produces:

  • Hydrogen Chloride (HCl)
  • Carbon Monoxide (CO)

Do not breathe exhaust fumes.

docs.title: Physical Properties
docs.text:
• Auto-ignition temperature: 550°F (288°C)
  • Propellant density: 0.058-0.065 lb/in³

docs.title: First Aid
docs.text:
• Inhalation: Move to fresh air, call physician if symptoms persist
  • Skin contact: Wash immediately
  • Burns: Immerse in cold water, seek medical attention for severe burns
  • Ingestion: Induce vomiting, call physician

docs.title: Fire Fighting
docs.text: Use water only. Foam and CO2 are ineffective. Motors may become propulsive in fire.

docs.title: Disposal
docs.text: Do not dispose in landfill or sewer. Burn in controlled manner: bury motor with only nozzle exposed, ignite electrically from safe distance.

docs.title: EU P2 Pyrotechnics Regulation
docs.text:
H-class motors are P2 category under EU Directive 2013/29/EU.

Per TTJA (Estonian Technical Regulatory Authority): Each EU member state determines P2 handling rules internally. In Estonia, the equipment producer should provide adequate training, which forms the basis for professional P2 device handling.

Training Adequacy

Whether reading the AeroTech SDS constitutes adequate "producer training" for Estonian P2 compliance is unclear. This is one reason for flying in Sweden where the regulatory framework is established.

docs.title: Reference
docs.text:
Apogee product page lists compatible motors: Peregrine on Apogee Rockets

Note: Most motors listed there are not available for purchase in Estonia/Europe. The H128W was selected based on what Swedish Tripoli members can provide locally.

docs.title: Source
docs.text:
RockSim file downloaded from Apogee Product Page:

  • Peregrine.rkt.zip

docs.title: Converting RockSim to OpenRocket
docs.text:
OpenRocket (free, open-source) can import RockSim .rkt files directly:

  1. Download and unzip RockSim file from Apogee
  2. Open OpenRocket
  3. File → Open → Select .rkt file
  4. OpenRocket imports automatically
  5. Save as .ork file

Fin Import

The curved Peregrine fins import correctly via this method. Manual recreation of the spline fin shape is difficult.

docs.title: Full L2 Configuration
docs.text:
Imported directly from Apogee's RockSim file.

Parameter OpenRocket Value Length 175 cm Max Diameter 10.2 cm Mass (no motor) 1096 g CG 92.7 cm CP 130 cm Stability 3.69 cal ✓

docs.title: L1 Minimal Configuration
docs.text:
Modified from L2 config by removing:

  • Electronics bay (E-bay coupler, bulkheads, sled, switch band)
  • Drogue parachute and associated hardware
  • Upper body tube section

Parameter OpenRocket Value Issue Length 126 cm Max Diameter 10.2 cm Mass (no motor) 1096 g Model needs mass override CG 92.73 cm CP 90.8 cm Stability -0.191 cal ⚠️ UNSTABLE

L1 Configuration is Unstable

The shortened L1 rocket has CP forward of CG, resulting in negative stability.

Root cause: Removing the e-bay section moves CP forward significantly (130cm → 90.8cm) while CG remains similar.

Solution: Add nose ballast to move CG forward of CP.

docs.title: Mass Discrepancy
docs.text:
Source Mass OpenRocket model 1096 g Actual rocket (weighed) 1460 g Difference 364 g

The 364g difference is accounted for by:

  • Epoxy fillets and bonding (~200-250g typical for 4" HPR)
  • Paint and primer (~50-100g)
  • Additional hardware, quick links
  • Nomex protector

Mass Override Required

The OpenRocket model significantly underestimates actual built mass.

After building, update the model:

  1. Click on top-level "Stage" in component tree
  2. Go to "Override" tab
  3. Check "Override mass"
  4. Enter measured mass: 1460 g
  5. Re-run stability calculations

docs.title: Stability Analysis with Ballast
docs.text:
With actual mass (1460g) concentrated more forward (due to epoxy in nose, etc.), the CG will shift forward. Additional nose ballast will be required.

Target: Stability margin ≥ 1.5 calibers (15.3 cm for 10.2 cm diameter)

See L1 Weight Budget for ballast calculations.

docs.title: Launch Site Conditions
docs.text:
For Långtora, Sweden (SMRK launch site):

Parameter Value Location Långtora, Sweden Altitude ~25 m ASL Temperature -5 to +5 °C (January) Pressure 1013 hPa (std) Wind Variable

docs.title: Motor: AeroTech H128W
docs.text:
To be simulated with corrected mass

Parameter Value Max Altitude TBD Max Velocity TBD Time to Apogee TBD Optimal Delay TBD Rail Exit Velocity TBD Stability (off rod) TBD

docs.title: Action Items
docs.text:
• [ ] Update OpenRocket model with actual mass (1460g)
  • [ ] Add nose ballast component to achieve positive stability
  • [ ] Calculate required ballast for 1.5+ caliber stability
  • [ ] Run flight simulations with H128W motor
  • [ ] Determine optimal delay time

docs.title: OpenRocket Files
docs.text: File Description openrocket/Peregrine.ork Full L2 config (from RockSim import) openrocket/PeregrineL1.ork L1 minimal config (needs work)

docs.title: Detailed Measurements
docs.text: Dimension Imperial Metric Total Length 68.8" 175 cm Body Diameter (OD) 4.0" 98mm Nose Cone (exposed) 19.8" 50 cm Nose Cone Shape 5:1 Ogive - Motor Tube (ID) 38mm - Motor Tube Length 11" 28 cm

docs.title: Fin Dimensions
docs.text:
The Peregrine features distinctive swept-back curved fins that extend below the body tube base.

Fin Geometry

The curved fin profile requires freeform or spline definition in OpenRocket. RockSim file from Apogee contains accurate fin geometry.

Parameter Value Fin Count 3 Material Birch plywood Attachment Through-the-wall (TTW) Extends Below Tube Yes

docs.title: Electronics Bay Dimensions
docs.text: Dimension Value E-Bay Diameter 98mm (4") Coupler OD Fits 98mm body tube Sled Width Fits inside coupler

docs.title: Recovery Bay Volumes
docs.text:
These volumes are important for calculating ejection charges:

Bay Location Notes Drogue Bay Forward (nose to e-bay) 18" drogue + protector Main Bay Aft (e-bay to fins) 48" main + protector

Volume Calculation

Use RockSim or OpenRocket to calculate exact bay volumes. See Ejection Charges for charge sizing.

docs.title: Kit Contents
docs.text: The Apogee Peregrine kit includes all components needed for a complete dual-deployment rocket build.

docs.title: Kit Identification
docs.text:
Info Value Kit Number 04998 Face Card P/N 39101 Barcode 656779049988 Age Rating 18+

Packaging vs Website Discrepancies

Item Packaging Website/Actual Skill Level 4 3 Height "Over 65"" 68.8" (175 cm)

docs.title: Airframe Components
docs.text: Component Description Body Tubes Heavy-wall kraft paper, white overwrap Coupler Tubes For joining sections Nose Cone (PNC-98) 5:1 ogive, polypropylene plastic Centering Rings Aviation plywood Bulkheads Plywood

docs.title: Fin Assembly
docs.text: Component Description Fins (3) Laser-cut birch plywood, swept-back curved shape Fin Alignment Interlocking support structure

docs.title: Motor Mount
docs.text:
Component Description Motor Tube 38mm diameter, heavy wall Centering Rings Plywood, sized for 38mm to 98mm Thrust Block Included (remove for longer motors)

Motor Retention

Motor retention is NOT included. Apogee recommends:

  • AeroPack 38L Engine Retainer
  • Fins & Fire 38mm Retainer
  • Or use masking tape (traditional method)

docs.title: Electronics Bay (E-Bay)
docs.text: Component Description E-Bay Tube 98mm diameter coupler Bulkheads Plywood with eyebolt holes Sled Plywood mounting platform Threaded Rod Single rod design (lighter than dual-rod) Switch Band For arming switch mounting Hardware Wing nut, washers, eyebolts

docs.title: Recovery System
docs.text: Component Size/Description Main Parachute 48" ripstop nylon, printed pattern Drogue Parachute 18" ripstop nylon Shock Cord (Main) Shorter cord, fluorescent orange tubular nylon Shock Cord (Drogue) Longer cord, fluorescent orange tubular nylon Chute Protectors 12" Nomex, reusable (2 included) Quick Links For easy parachute attachment

docs.title: Finishing
docs.text: Component Description Vinyl Decals 2 full sheets (color + metallic silver) Rail Buttons For launch rail guidance Plastic Rivets For securing e-bay to airframe

docs.title: Not Included (Required)
docs.text:
• Motor retention system
  • Altimeter/flight computer
  • Ejection charge canisters (for dual deploy)
  • Black powder or CO2 cartridges
  • E-matches or igniters
  • Epoxy (5-minute and 30-minute recommended)
  • Paint and primer
  • Motors

docs.title: Optional Accessories
docs.text:
• 29/38mm Motor Adapter (for test flights on G motors)
  • AeroPack Motor Retainer
  • GPS Tracker
  • Keychain camera with aerodynamic shroud

docs.title: Body Tubes
docs.text:
Property Value Material Kraft paper Wall Type Heavy wall Surface White glassine overwrap Spiral Tight wound

Characteristics:

  • Easy to mark with pencil
  • Tight spirals minimize filling work
  • White surface shows construction marks clearly
  • Can be reinforced with fiberglass if desired

docs.title: Centering Rings & Bulkheads
docs.text: Property Value Material Aviation plywood Cut Method Laser cut Finish Requires light sanding on edges

docs.title: Fins
docs.text: Property Value Material Aeronautical birch plywood Cut Method Laser cut Profile Swept-back curved Grain Oriented for maximum strength

docs.title: Nose Cone Material
docs.text:
Property Value Material Polypropylene plastic Flexibility Moderate flex (impact resistant) Paint Adhesion Requires adhesion promoter

Painting Polypropylene

Polypropylene does not accept paint well. Use:

  1. Clean surface thoroughly
  2. Apply adhesion promoter (plastic primer)
  3. Apply regular primer
  4. Paint as normal

docs.title: Parachutes
docs.text: Property Value Material Thin-mill ripstop nylon Feel Soft, silk-like Shroud Lines Double-looped at canopy Packing Very compact

docs.title: Shock Cord
docs.text: Property Value Type Tubular nylon Color Fluorescent orange Visibility High (aids recovery)

docs.title: Chute Protectors
docs.text: Property Value Material Nomex cloth Size 12" diameter Quantity 2 (one per bay) Reusability Fully reusable

docs.title: Recommended Construction Adhesives
docs.text: Application Recommended General Assembly 5-minute epoxy Fin Fillets 30-minute epoxy or Rocketpoxy High-Stress Joints JB Weld or 30-minute epoxy Motor Retainer High-temperature epoxy (JB Weld) Quick Tacks Thick CA (cyanoacrylate)

docs.title: Material Strengths
docs.text:
Construction Philosophy

The Peregrine uses traditional rocketry materials:

  • Proven reliability
  • Easy to work with
  • Familiar to most builders
  • Good strength-to-weight ratio
  • Economical

For extreme applications, tubes can be reinforced with fiberglass cloth.

docs.title: Apogee Peregrine Overview
docs.text: The Peregrine is a high-power dual-deployment rocket designed by Apogee Components. It features distinctive swept-back curved fins and is intended for fliers who already have (or are pursuing) Level 1 certification.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Dual Deployment Ready: Includes electronics bay, dual parachutes, and all hardware
  • Distinctive Fin Design: Swept-back curved birch plywood fins extend below the base tube
  • Large Size: 68.8" length makes it highly visible during flight
  • Traditional Construction: Kraft paper tubes, plywood centering rings, wooden components
  • Detailed Instructions: Apogee provides comprehensive step-by-step build documentation

docs.title: Primary Specifications
docs.text: Specification Value Metric Overall Length 68.8" 175 cm Body Diameter 4.0" 98mm Nose Cone Length 19.8" exposed 50 cm Nose Cone Type 5:1 Ogive - Dry Weight ~5+ lbs ~2.3+ kg Motor Mount 38mm - Fin Count 3 - Fin Material Birch plywood -

docs.title: Nose Cone Details
docs.text:
The PNC-98 nose cone:

  • 5:1 length-to-diameter ogive shape
  • Made from polypropylene plastic (flexible, impact resistant)
  • Requires adhesion promoter before priming/painting
  • Super-strong attachment loop for shock cord

docs.title: Recovery System
docs.text: Component Size Main Parachute 48" (122 cm) nylon Drogue Parachute 18" (45 cm) nylon Shock Cord Fluorescent orange tubular nylon Chute Protectors 12" Nomex (2 included)

docs.title: For L1 Certification (38mm motors)
docs.text:
• AeroTech H100W
  • AeroTech H180W
  • AeroTech H210 Redline
  • AeroTech H220T
  • Cesaroni H180

docs.title: Test Flights (29mm with adapter)
docs.text:
• AeroTech G80T (max non-HP motor)
  • Various G motors with 29/38mm adapter

Certification Advice

Apogee recommends NOT using dual deployment for L1/L2 certification flights. Use single deployment with motor ejection for simplicity.
